t-GOkzoM6PazEOdwsatkNQ.text: Stumbled upon this newly opened fastfood joint on the first day of its opening, when i was walking around my neighbourhood looking for some 'light' dinner.  Being a fan of japanese food, I decided to give it a try.  As per its name, one can pretty much guess what they serve... they serve low carb burritos-sized sushi rolls. I tried their " Rising Sun" ...Its pretty good... except I would preferred it with less wasabi.   They also served other side dishes. On the whole, its pretty yummy! Would love to go back and try the other items on their menu.

YRhrKMdspMoFe2N0WCQ0xQ.text: The oultet was located at the ground floor of one end of 100AM. There was limited dining in area. So I had the food taken away.SIGNATURE FRIED BACK ROLL ($6.90/ half roll)MAIN: Crab Meat, TamagoGREENS: Lettuce, Cucumber, AvocadoTOPPINGS: Flying Fish Roe, CheeseCal: 227 kcal The roll looked ugly. It had quite oily taste although it had the right texture with the chewy rice, juicy crab meat and tamago, and the popping fish roe. But it was just too oily to have. SAMURAI CHICKEN ($6.90/ half roll)MAIN: Fried Popcorn ChickenGREENS: Red Green Yellow Capsicum, Green Coral Lettuce, Japanese Cucumber, Takuan, AlfalfaTOPPINGS: Togarashi Powder (Spicy)Cal: 228 kcal Crunchy vegetables, although wished that the popcorn chicken was be crispier.TUNA SASHIMI SALAD ($7.90)DRESSING: Wasabi & Yuzu SauceCal: 250 kcalThere was not enough dressing to coat the salad evenly. The tuna sashimi tasted a bit off to me.FOREST SALAD ($7.90)MAIN: Sauteed MushroomDRESSING: Wafu SauceCal: 200 kcalThe mushrooms were well cooked but the dish was let down by the over used of black pepper here. It just tasted of black pepper which covered the nature taste of mushrooms.Service not bad, but the food got to improve some.

photos.caption: Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore

zOFYh-KdfE2vss_aw3SKBg.text: I had the beef sushi burrito and that was pretty tasty. The half portion was quite big. It did get messy towards the end as unlike a proper wrap, it is only the paper covering the end of the roll. I do wonder what will happen to the other half when someone just order a half portion. The potato salad was good, typical Japanese style. The salad was also refreshing but it was not very filling. So do not order just that if you are feeling hungry. The can of royal milk tea was not that great as it was not sweet or milky enough for my liking. Maybe I am too used to the Taiwanese style milk tea now.

photos.caption: Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Japanese milk tea is not very sweet or milky.
Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Size of half roll portion
Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Beef sushi and potato salad burrito

UCbOLvibY8eGIQsfrZMPTA.text: Great place for pre or post workout snack. The Skinny Sumo contains a great mix of protein (tuna, salmon and "crab") and veggies (lettuce, cucumbers, avocado and radish).  No rice. Perfect for the healthy eater.

photos.caption: Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Potato salad

D20aEuYf0XCkFUDMhF6-FQ.text: A highly disappointing meal. Got the rising sun (salmon and crab meat) burrito ($6.90 for half) and was attached by an overpowering taste of wasabi on the first bite. The wasabi sauce was unevenly squeezed and the burrito was not wrapped properly, causing bits of salmon, crab meat and lettuce to fall out even before the third mouth. I wouldn't have minded the mess if the taste made up for it, but it was nothing exceptional (maybe exceptionally messy and exceptionally overpriced). The seating here is spacious but there are few tables available, though it is rather empty during a weekday lunch hour (while the nearby toastbox, tsujiri and subway are all filled). Overall, I wouldn't recommend this place unless there is really no other choice - it wouldn't make good for a quick grab as well as the waiting time for the food was also significantly long.

photos.caption: Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Staff preparing the sushi
Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Rising sun

XeJvcqrN7jtFoKgYZxibWA.text: What is a sushi burrito? A big fat sushi. Sucks because you only get one flavor. The bottom line, a normal roll is better. I prefer my sushi bite sized and small enough so that I can dip them in my wasabi soy sauce concoction. Overall, this wouldn't be a place that I would come too often. Funny bc I'm currently the Duchess as I write this post, and the reason why I checked three times was because I purchased three Groupon vouchers. I would come back, but not because of cravings, solely bc of convenience. At the same time, I prefer the standard supermarket sushi downstairs at FairPrice Finest.  The food isn't anything to rave about and definitely can't be compared to the sushi rolls we have in the States (Lion King or Dragon Roll anyone?).

photos.caption: Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Store front

B5r7-vognmHYQ9qggd3-fQ.text: Who doesn't like a good Mashup. Two great cuisines. Mexican style with Japanese ingredients, the concept is amazing. After a short metro ride and 300m walk from the station we made it to Sushi Burrito. I was so hungry that I quickly ordered a beer and a fried back roll. This was a roll filled with crab meat, tamango, lettuce, cucumber, and avocado. I was really happy with my order. I'd definitely come again.

photos.caption: Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Fried back roll
Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Sign
Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Front window

7FjGY-edjN7_0XYaBCxAUw.text: I often get take out for my family. It's a relatively healthy option that's also low carb - it's stuffed full of ingredients and rolled with minimal rice. The flavour can't be compared to mid-range sushi restaurants but hey, it's a very respectable value-for-money burrito. Great all in one meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Sushi Burrito - Singapore, Singapore. Two full sushi burritos

MtSZHcFm7goGl0TliLahfQ.text: Not a great home delivery choice - maybe it's better when you dine in. The tempura roll was the lesser of two evils (2.5 stars) but the rice was mushy so don't expect any bite in the seaweed. Perhaps they could pack their seaweed separately so it's dry and crispy for you to wrap on when it arrives - Equinox and Swissotel used to serve their sushi at their Sunday brunch buffet like that. I couldn't take more than two bites of the other option (which had what looked like crabstick and raw tuna or salmon - my friends placed the order so I don't know what they're called) (1 star). The raw fish didn't taste fresh and made me nauseated.

v2i0AJKyR4HYksrbPt7grQ.text: I like their take on low-carb and calorie menu items by offering "skinny burritos" (hold the rice). It's always refreshing to see a place promote healthy alternatives. Their portions are not overwhelming creating a clean/bite size experience. I enjoyed the Geisha Dance and Rising Sun; both delicious.
